comments.commentBody:
I hail the old yaller cab. And I'm an old Silicon Valley techie.

"By any means necessary" may be a necessary strategy to resist our new authoritarian president. But it has no place in a business plan, except perhaps one for the Church of Scientology.

Actually, I'm pretty sure those laws and regulations were designed to protect the taxi cab industry from competition, at the expense of the public.  Objectively, the public loves Uber as demonstrated by how many people choose to use it.  It's not hard to figure out why it's popular:  they provide better service for lower prices, dramatically improving the ability of city dwellers to get around conveniently and affordably.  As far as "the law" goes, I applaud them for helping their drivers evade the cops.  Unjust laws deserve to be broken.

Laws are just opinions with guns. "legal" and "moral" are completely different concepts. Indeed, much of what today is legal (eg taxation) is immoral, and much of what is illegal (eg trading freely) is moral.
The whole thing is a farce which restrains trade and forecloses the market to competition at the expense of the consumer and Uber can take states to court for their anti-competitive behavior.
What kind of information is the government collecting. I prefer to trust Uber over an organization that has the power to incarcerate and execute me.

Uber, Lyft, Arbnb and the like undermine institutions set in place to protect customers. I know some people will argue that the taxi industry is no longer the little guy with a chance to make middle class wages. If this is the issue, the "sharing economy" is not solving this problem either.  Regulations are in place to provide safe  transactions and systems of liabilities. Of course there can be problems with regulations, but these are fixable.  When I think of Lyft, Uber, and Airbnb, I think of weaker economies where there are no rules. Uber is a glorified rickshaw. Regulations keep us in a first world status. This deregulation economy throws us in with the like of the free-for-all of third world economies.  I see these companies as a step backwards, not forwards. I want my lodgings to have to play by the rules. I want my driver to have laws to uphold. Well enforced regulations are not bad things. That is why when we have earthquakes so few people die. In places like Turkey or China you have thousands dead. Deregulated countries are not ones where the rule of law predominates. With all its problems, I'll take the rule of law any day.

According to laws passed by municipal politicians taking campaign contributions from taxi interests, yes. Racial integration was also illegal. Distinguish between actions that are intrinsically wrong, like armed robbery, and actions which may be illegal but are intrinsically morally neutral and have been made illegal by parties with something to gain for doing so.

This just in: People Hate Uber. Wow! All the outrage is far too late for me. I was forced to sell my taxi business three years ago. Uber was never anything more than a gypsy cab service funded by gobs of venture capitol. Uber drivers were essentially scabs who poured in to cities to destroy taxi industries. Uber delivers rides from point A to B. They have an app. Cabs take people from point A to B. They have insurance, worker's comp and, in my city, are required to abide by numerous government regulations including a requirement to run green vehicles. Now cabs have apps too. It cracks me up that many liberals who claim to have concern for working people and the environment are among the biggest consumers of Uber and Lyft. So sad to hear your favorite cool business has disappointed you.
Right. It's all the liberal's fault.   Hillary is probably behind it.

No. People love uber
People hate dirty rude taxis

People love Uber! (As evidenced by their huge ridership.)
It is far more efficient use of resources (thus better for the environment and society in many ways).
It provides those without steady jobs income and dignity, and flexibility.
For its customers, it provides a top level of convenience (the polar opposite of taxis).
To blame Uber for the demise of the taxi industry is like blaming air travel for decline of long haul passenger trains, or synthetic fabrics for the decline of wool recycling.
Bravo and thank you, Uber!

Stewart went to jail specifically for directly lying to an FBI agent, which is a type of obstructing justice charge. Uber was facilitating their subcontractors avoiding entrapment by deception. It looks the same from a lay perspective, but legally, it's different.

We do not all use Uber and many of us do not use any of these shady unlicensed Taxi services. Also up to question is liability if an accident happens, as most auto policies do not cover commercial use of a car for a personal policy.
Ride at your own risk. I will stick to my personal car or a rental.

If Uber is cheaper and more convenient for the riders, and most riders choose Uber because they provide a better deal than Taxi, isn't the problem overregulation that makes Taxi uncompetitive? It's surreal and sad that Taxi drivers are attacking Uber rather than attacking those who have put horrendously costly regulations in place to make them so uncompetitive. In the end the ones who lose out will be the riders/consumers yet again if Uber is taken down or made to become as expensive as Taxi

Gennifer Flowers from Arkansas (born January 24, 1950) is an American model and actress who obtained notoriety after revealing a sexual encounter with U.S. President Bill Clinton.

Clinton aggressively denied the affair until he admitted it--- after he became president. It them southern boys

I think the weight and scope of this job will end up crushing Trump because he lacks the temperment, focus and discipline to handle the challenge. To his core, Trump is insecure, hence the need for constant adoration and praise. While he acts tough, Trump is very thin-skinned. While a bigger person, secure and confident in their own beliefs would brush aside criticism, Trump is completely derailed by it. By all accounts, Trump spends a great deal of his time obsessing over television news coverage of him.

For a man whose path to the presidency was strewn with the bodies and careers of friend and foe alike, we can be certain that the attacks and critcism will be a constant. Trump cannot help but engage.

Much has been written about his speech to Congress. It is odd to see a president get such lofty praise for doing little more than meeting the minimum requirements of the job--acting presidential. Nevertheless, it has been well-established that for brief interludes, Trump read from a teleprompter, the gentle musings of his speechwriters. At such times, he seems passably sane. But these fits of normalcy are the rare exception. When he is allowed off his leash, the Real Donald reclaims the mantle of bully-amateur-blowhard in all it ugliness.

Frankly it is a relief. Congress is paralyzed by its own internal squabbles and Trump is at war with a nameless, faceless enemy. Let's hope the mid-terms come before these clowns get their act together.

This is something that continues to make me laugh, that Democrats are seriously believing that in the mid term elections, they will find more support. You can get Trump and his entire administration out of office, that is entirely possible. After all, the minute he was elected, all the Democrats decided to organize and do just that. Everything that has happened since the election was purposeful and the intention of the Democratic party - to wrestle power from the new administration.

But you delude yourself to think that people are too stupid to realize that is what you are doing. Then you elect Perez and Ellison to the head of the Democratic party, and you still convince yourself that you somehow hold the higher ground. You may be more polished then Trump, but you are acting in ways that are no better than those you criticize him for.

You think Congress is paralyzed now, wait? It was for the past 8 years, and Democrats are determined we'll spend another 4 years paralyzed. No governing is going on at all. You're all bringing the country down with your own hands. So I have no idea how you are relieved. Going forward, you can count on more of the same. Democrats put themselves in power by finding a way to get Trump out and you think people are going to support you?

I agree completely. Ezra Klein interviews Elizabeth Drew in a recent podcast in which she expresses much the same assessment of Trump and suggests that he may not even complete his term due to his temperamental shortcomings for "the job". I believe his autocratic streak will eventually result in a major blunder.

I think there is something to the Russian connections; to my knowledge Manafort is more involved in Ukrainian politics than US politics when he is tapped to replace Trump's campaign manager (Lewandowski) after he causes embarrassment by pushing around the press at a campaign rally. And then Trump begins the "wikileaks" mantra which carries all the way through to election day.

Let's hope the Democrats get their act together by the mid-terms so that they can present some candidates that are attractive to the electorate which I believe will be less complacent than at the presidential election.

Thank you for sharing your insights, Al. In today's Wall St Journal, Peggy Noonan clutched her pearls and marveled at 45's speech to Congress, saying how the rest of the world saw how presidential he is, and could now see what his supporters have seen all along. She concluded, breathlessly, that he may have a capacity to grow into the office. Based on what, I have no idea. He's 70 years old and has yet to show growth anywhere.  He's the same petty, bombastic, lying narcissist he's always been. And always will be.

trump has brought this on himself. He lies, his people lie. It may be true that campaigns meet with foreign governments, but I believe that his people are so sensitized to trumps own Russia entanglements that any forthright mention of meetings bring with them the fear of  exposing trump. He came in as an autocrat believing he could bully and lie and everyone would roll over. He refuses to release his taxes with the feeble excuse that they are under audit. Even by his son's admission he has financial ties to Russia that may prove to be compromising at best. It is obvious he is hiding something. If  it were simply some principled stance than he should early on have expressed and defended it, but he chose to hide behind the audit ploy.  He is, if nothing else, financially entwined to these people and needs to come clean about it. It is poisoning his presidency. Welcome to birther karma mr trump show us your taxes!

It is vital to resist these phony attempts at normalization. Supposedly routine contacts are anything but when a national election has been hacked, especially when the contacts are subsequently denied by the president and officials directly involved. Routine contacts do not require this level of concealment. There is nothing normal here.

James,

You say that you're "sick of the Russia bashing", but the Russians are not being "bashed" . The Russians are doing what Russians do, trying to influence elections, not just in the US but throughout Europe, by funding, openly or not, the campaigns of the so called populist parties which have crawled out of their caves in the last decade . If the Russians believe that it is in the interest of their country to interfere, why condemn them ? The US has a history of doing precisely the same when it was deemed to be in the interest of the country .

The problem is that there is a likelihood, however small, that a US campaign abetted in this effort . It is difficult to reconcile various statements made during the campaign that Trump had a "relationship, both direct and indirect" (whatever that means) with Putin, with the more recent assertion that he "did not know Putin" and "had nothing to do with Russia" when Trump Jr. asserted that the Trump Organization saw "money pouring in from Russia" . As to the trickle of information about previously denied contacts with the Russian officials, e.g. Kushner's meeting with the Russian ambassador at Trump Tower, they certainly suggest a certain closeness .

There is no "anti Russian hysteria" . There is a concern, which could easily be allayed by an independent investigation, that the Trump campaign was not forthright in its description of Russian contacts . Why do Republicans object to such an investigation ?

I certainly don't want another Cold War, so Russia shouldn't be treated as an outright enemy, but neither is it our friend. Weakening Western nations to give himself a freer hand is one of Vladimir Putin's major ambitions, and we must not ignore that. Our past sins do not justify his.

Moreover, when has any presidential administration been so riddled with connections to an unfriendly foreign government? Some of those connections may be unimportant or tangential, but Manafort, Tillerson, and Trump himself have had years-long relationships with the Russian government. The situation is bizarre and quite possibly unprecedented in American history. We have to know what's going on here.

What is the base allegation fueling all of the anti-Russian hysteria?

It is that they hacked some private, non-governmental emails and exposed some uncomfortable truths. Not that they lied. Not that they actually tampered with the voting process. Simply that they revealed secrets to influence public opinion.

In a similar way, a private conversation between Billy Bush and Donald Trump (i.e. “grab women by the …) was secretly recorded and later revealed to the public. That did far more political damage to Trump than the Russian hacking did to Clinton.

Are liberals upset about this case of illegally leaking secrets? Not so much.

Nice try. No, it's that they lied: Flynn. Sessions. Trump, too, over and again, every time the subject comes up. Cover-up apparently worse than the crime, but ... maybe the crime actually is worse in this case.

Liberals were THRILLED and giddy with joy when the Billy Bush tapes were revealed -- even though they were 12 year old, PRIVATE conversations taped without the participants knowledge or consent.It "proved" Trump was a dirty old man.

Liberals were THRILLED and giddy with joy to get Trump's 1995 tax return -- with a $960,000,000 deduction on it! No matter it was perfectly legal and accepted by the IRS as a valid tax return. It "proved" Trump was an evil rich guy!

None of this, of course, worked to destroy Trump. Indeed, it backfired on liberals and made them look petty and venal.

When Edward Snowden and Julian Assange "leaked" information damaging to the Bush Administration, liberals were overjoyed. Now...not so much. Suddenly they HATE Wikileaks, where previously they often called for Snowden and Assange to get amnesty as "heroes".

Frankly, this all smacks of A. hypocrisy and B. poor sportsmanship. You lost, guys. Get over it.

This is one big experiment and findings keep rolling in for the investigator--Vladimir P.
This is a multi-year ( in its 10th year), two-arm study of the effects of multifactorial inputs on internal and international political behavior of the US.
Question: If inputs of disinformation, long-term"relationships," flattery, financial promise and actual reward are applied to the American system, can the results be measured and adapted to the advantage of the investigator?
secondary question: without awareness of American participants?
Design:
1. cultivate relationships in both parties; obtain "secure" information in both parties' data bases and emails; release quanta of disinformation in many modalities via various intermediaries
2. measure response of Rep. and Dem. parties + individuals to release of disinformation; compare the public comments by people befriended by the Russian Ambassador and others whose conversations are all taped and monitored
3. only release information helpful to one presidential candidate and party. Continue to monitor how each person and party responds as disinformation is explained, distorted, uncovered. Monitor media response speed to evaluate+ communicate. Is there a court response? Monitor how it is received and understood by public and by subgroups of interest.
4.Continue to adapt for more effective manipulation + disruption. Provide photos of opposition party meeting with Ambassador and other ways to deny, obfuscate and portray as victim.
And all for a couple Million per Annum

The one thing that continues to puzzle me about this story is why any Americans associated (no matter how remotely associated) with a Presidential campaign would be in contact with representatives of a foreign government.  The purpose of a campaign is to elect someone to political office.  Contacting a foreign goverment to discuss diplomatic issues while another President is in office is reprehensible.

Getting background information to build a platform and prepare for a transition is reasonable, as is building personal relationships for the future. Making promises about what your party will do if you win is "diplomacy" and violates the Logan act.

The rationale for the investigative reportage and official government investigation is clear and easy: firstly, the vainglorious presidential candidate expressed admiration for Mr. Putin, a rather odd thing for someone who wanted to lead the USA. During that period, security and law agencies discovered that Russia had used digital means to influence public opinion and embarrass the other candidate and her party. Secondly, having been elected, the new president  appointed two officials who lied under oath about their contacts with Russian government officials and influential people. Don't forget about the euro-spy who issued a report that the vainglorious presidential candidate had been compromised  by the Russians while he was in Russia (that spy had disappeared). No substance has been found, but the whole thing reeks and NYT reporters should stay on the scent.

No, Mark, you have the wrong "underlying assumption" . That Secretary Clinton lost is clear and the reasons for that loss are probably multi-faceted . The true underlying assumption is that trump and his associates may have been less than forthright in their denials and later explanations of the extent of their relations with Russian officials .

In any normal circumstance, an independent investigation would have been commissioned, if only to clarify the issue once and for all . Why do Republicans so strenuously oppose it ? It seems to me that they would loudly call for it, if only to show the opposition that their suspicions were both ludicrous and politically motivated .

By the way, the Russians are not being blamed . If there is any blame to assess it would be on those, if any, who colluded with them . I am not suggesting that anybody actually did, but I would like to be reassured .

Two points are relevant here, that of fathoming Russian intent and interpretation of their stance.

Given that Russian economy is in dire straits, sanctioned off from west and constrained to increasingly tilit towards China, providing them with its state of art defense equipments, the intent of mostly Euro-centric Russian strategists would be to normalize with West.

This stance came about because they are weak and vulnerable, not strong enough to ward off threats. What real impact their desperate and concerted efforts had on outcome of November elections is unknown. Being weak, and given the stances taken by two campaigns, instead of hedging their bet, it seems they opted to gamble on the side which looked like winning both Houses, but not the Presidency.

If Russia is not perceived as strong and threatening, a defensive, shrill posture does not serve any productive purpose. Understanding their motives, and negotiating sensibly to resolve issues and prepare for real, credible threats is in order. The policy on how to deal with it can emerge only from proper assessments of security scene and risks.

Subjecting this matter to partisan grind is not the answer, since the stakes for future of western world and elsewhere is much too high. As an Indian-American, with a fair tilt towards Russia, my view perhaps reflects an inherent bias, stating so, hopefully enables factoring it.

Is it true that American banks would not lend Trump money because so many of his investments went under (at least, for his investors). One of his sons is reported to have stated a year or so ago that there was a lot of Russian money invested in Trump businesses. Certainly, the Russian oligarchs are known for laundering their money in overseas investments that they can trust to keep things hidden. Such financial arrangements could explain a lot about Trump's behavior toward the Russians, and raise serious questions about potential Russian influence on the Trump presidency.

This "whataboutism" concerning Senator Schumer's meeting with Putin is a telling defensive move: It's an old Soviet propaganda trick, responding to a criticism or allegation with false equivalence directed at one's adversaries.

It won't work. The steady, daily, drip-drip-drip of news about previously denied contacts between the Trump campaign and Russian officials can't be blithely dismissed by waving about a 2003 photo of a sitting U.S. senator eating a doughnut with a visiting Russian president.

It's high time to have an independent special prosecutor appointed, with full subpoena powers, and get this investigation started for real.

I don't agree with that. There is also a photo of Nancy Pilosi with Kislyak floating around, after she also said she had no contact. So why is that not relevant? It's not about defense, it's about putting something in perspective and determining what is impartial and objective.

Washington is a swamp, but apparently, Democrats believe only Trump and his team are residents of a swamp. The Democrats think they live on the top of the mountain. They've been investigating since the campaign. So where's the evidence? More innuendo and supposition, speculation. Get some facts! And as long as that is all it takes to convince Democrats to start screaming for everyone's resignation, then you are showing your colors. You are not interested in fair, objective or facts. Democrats made up their mind to get rid of Trump the minute he was elected and everything that followed, is that organized attempt to do so.
